 Now that the US debt ceiling has again been officially increased, if it doesn't happen this week Japan and China will soon buy a wad of dollars and treasury issues to shore it up somewhat as soon as the flood of Xmas consumer goods has been added to the import tab. That'll shut the administration up for a few weeks until the fed again raises interest rates. I wonder how the average person will react to US Government public political claims of 'letting the dollar float to make US exports more attractive in world markets' when the realization hits them that dollar bills serve family purchasing needs formerly filled by the now somewhat copper $.25 piece. 
 
 I'm no longer active in the industry, but the dollar has to be creating nightmares in the international lending community. Are loans still assembled using periodic exchange rate adjustments as the lender hedge or are other factors now involved on a frequent adjustment basis? Ironic in that those tools were formerly in place to protect dollar based investments. Gotta be ugly for dollar people capping off-shore subs no matter what but fun to put together and providing some interesting impacts on financial business models.
